resource.name: Census Tracts
resource.description: Census Tracts are determined by the U.S. Census Bureau for calculating the decennial census. Census tracts are a subdivision of the County level and vary in size. Ideally a census tract contains a population of 4,000 people and 1,600 housing units. 209 census tracts intersect or fall within the City of Memphis boundary.

resource.name: FY20 MWBE Gender & Ethnicity Report
resource.description:
This dataset shows the breakdown of City of Memphis FY20 spend with minority and women owned business enterprises (MWBEs) by gender and ethnicity. 

*Unallocated represents those checks that were not attributed to a division at the time of payment.
**Public Works spent an additional $19,956,641.03 with MWBE firms through the Sewer Assessment and Rehabilitation Program, which is managed by Black and Veatch. This amount is not included in the official report because it is managed by an outside entity. However, if that amount were included, Public Works percent MWBE spend would be 24.5%.
***Retirement investment, money manager, and custodian fees are excluded from eligible spend in this report, but will be included in a separate report produced by the Finance Division and Investment Manager.
****In the event that a business is eligible for both MBE and WBE certifications, the MBE certification is counted. However, a business may elect to maintain only a WBE certification. As a result, the Caucasian Female dollar percent will not exactly match the WBE percent.

resource.name: Walkability Index
resource.description: The Walkability Index dataset characterizes every Census 2010 block group in the U.S. based on its relative walkability. Walkability depends upon characteristics of the built environment that influence the likelihood of walking being used as a mode of travel. The Walkability Index is based on the EPA's previous data product, the Smart Location Database (SLD). Walkabilty has been linked to increased physical activity and stronger social ties within the communities, promoting better health outcomes than less walkable areas.
columns_description: Geometry of census tracts used to map them in GIS
Census tract ID
The street intersection density  is ranked (1 to 20) by block group. The higher the score the more dense the intersections are which increases the overall walkabilty of a census tract.

The walkabilty Index is ranked (1 to 20) by census tract. The higher the score the more walkable the census tract is. The scores are categorized into 4 groups: 1-5.75 (least walkable), 5.76- 10.50 (Below Average Walkabale), 10.51- 15.25  (Above Average Walkable), 15.26-20 (Most Walkable)

resource.name: FY21 MWBE Citywide Spend by Gender/Ethnicity Report
resource.description:
This dataset shows the breakdown of City of Memphis FY21 spend with minority and women owned business enterprises (MWBEs) by gender and ethnicity.

Footnotes
1. Unallocated represents those checks that were not attributed to a division at the time of payment.
2. Retirement investment, money manager, and custodian fees are excluded from eligible spend in this report, but will be included in a separate report produced by the Finance Division and Investment Manager.
3. In the event that a business is eligible for both MBE and WBE certifications, the MBE certification is counted. However, a business may elect to maintain only a WBE certification. As a result, the Caucasian Female dollar percent will not exactly match the WBE percent.
4. Payments to subcontractors are reported by prime contractors on a monthly basis, the total of which is reflected in Column J above. In some cases, depending on the date of prime payment and the date of reported sub payment, these payments could be split across reporting periods. In rare cases, this could result in a percentage over 100% due to the denominator being captured in one report, and the numerator being captured in the following report.

resource.name: MPD Police Stations: Uniform Patrol Division
resource.description: The data set describes the 9 Police Stations operated under the Uniform Patrol Division of the Memphis Police Department (MPD). The Uniform Patrol Division is the largest division within the MPD and is responsible for responding to calls that occur within the City's 9 precincts. All 9 stations contain a  General Investigations Bureau, responsible for the investigation of the following criminal offenses: Accidental Injury, Aggravated Assault, Simple Assault, Animal Injury, Bribery, Burglary, Escapee, Intimidation, Motor Vehicle Theft, Pocket Picking, Robbery, Shoplifting, Suspicious Person, Theft, Threatening Phone Call, Obscene/Harassing Phone Call, Vandalism, Stolen Property, False Reporting, and Fire Alarms.
columns_description: The 6 sub-divisions of each precinct the coresponding station is responsible for
The Police Stations are named according to the name of the street that is contained within the station's address
Precincts are MPD defined areas of coverage. Each Precinct area coresponds to a Police Station Location and is classified using the station's name (based on the station's street name)
The 9 stations/ precincts of MPD's Uniform Patrol Division are organized into District 1 or District 2

resource.name: FY20 Minority & Women Owned Business Enterprises (MWBE) Spend Report
resource.description:
This dataset shows the breakdown of City of Memphis FY20 spend with minority and women owned business enterprises. The breakdown includes data for all divisions in addition to a citywide total.

*Unallocated represents those checks that were not attributed to a division at the time of payment.

**Public Works spent an additional $19,956,641.03 with MWBE firms through the Sewer Assessment and Rehabilitation Program, which is managed by Black and Veatch. This amount is not included in the official report because it is managed by an outside entity. However, if that amount were included, Public Works percent MWBE spend would be 24.5%.

***Retirement investment, money manager, and custodian fees are excluded from eligible spend in this report, but will be included in a separate report produced by the Finance Division and Investment Manager.

****In the event that a business is eligible for both MBE and WBE certifications, the MBE certification is counted. However, a business may elect to maintain only a WBE certification. As a result, the Caucasian Female dollar percent will not exactly match the WBE percent.
columns_name: Percent Certified + Non Certified MWBE Spend

2. Retirement investment, money manager, and custodian fees are excluded from eligible spend in this report, but will be included in a separate report produced by the Finance Division and Investment Manager.														
3. In the event that a business is eligible for both MBE and WBE certifications, the MBE certification is counted. However, a business may elect to maintain only a WBE certification. As a result, the Caucasian Female dollar percent will not exactly match the WBE percent.														
4. Payments to subcontractors are reported by prime contractors on a monthly basis, the total of which is reflected in Column J above. In some cases, depending on the date of prime payment and the date of reported sub payment, these payments could be split across reporting periods. In rare cases, this could result in a percentage over 100% due to the denominator being captured in one report, and the numerator being captured in the following report.
columns_name: Percent Certified + Non Certified MWBE Spend

resource.name: Residential & Commercial Alarms
resource.description:
This dataset shows detailed information related to the operation of the City's Metro Alarm Office, including the number of permits issued and the number of false alarms recorded each month.

Please note: From July 2017-present, the columns "False Alarms" and False Alarms Historical" are identical. Prior to the ordnance passed in June 2017, the only false alarms that could be counted were those verified and matched by MPD's reporting database. This is reflected in the "False Alarms" column, pre July 2017. In order to get a true reflection of the volume of historical false alarms, dispatched records were matched and aggregated. This is reflected in the column "False Alarms Historical," pre July 2017.
columns_description: Residential alarm permits added during the reporting month
Total dollar amount charged
Commercial alarm permits added during the reporting month
Reporting month & year (date rounds to 1st of the month)
Dollar amount collected during reporting month
Please see dataset description for further explanation.
Reporting year
Total false alarms received during the reporting month
Dollar amount billed during reporting month
Reporting month
Month order (1=January, 12=December)
Number of accounts that were charged for their 3rd false alarm.

resource.name: Memphis 3.0 Focus Anchors Buffers
resource.description: Shapefile of the buffers around the initial 6 focus anchors for metric tracking.

resource.name: Drainage Basins
resource.description: The City of Memphis Engineering Department – Mapping Division created the drainage basins based on watersheds. In general, watersheds delineate an area or region drained by a river, river system, or other body of water. The drainage basins in this layer are based on a hierarchical system of hydrologic units. These hydrologic units have several levels of geographical sized areas, the smallest of which is the subwatershed. The subwatershed level serves the purposes of the Engineering Department regarding their sanitary and stormwater efforts. The basins in this layer contain subwatersheds, and in some instances the subwatersheds have been divided further based on the modeling needs of the Engineering Department.
